verses.text: Now these are the nations which the LORD left, to test Israel by them—that is, all who had not known all the wars of Canaan—
verses.comment: Introduces nations left to test Israel, connecting to the previous chapter.

verses.text: Only so that the generations of the people of Israel might know war, to teach war to those who had not known it before—
verses.comment: Clarifies God's purpose in leaving the nations: to train a new generation.

verses.text: the five lords of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites who lived on Mount Lebanon, from Mount Baal-hermon as far as Lebo-hamath.
verses.comment: Geographical note: Mount Baal-hermon marks Israel's northern border.

verses.text: They were left to test Israel by them, to know whether they would obey the commandments of the LORD, which He commanded their fathers by the hand of Moses.
verses.comment: Highlights the testing purpose, referencing the Law of Moses.

verses.text: So the people of Israel lived among the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
verses.comment: Lists the inhabitants with whom Israel dwelt, showing incomplete conquest.

verses.text: And they took their daughters as wives for themselves, and gave their own daughters to their sons, and served their gods.
verses.comment: Note: Intermarriage forbidden in Mosaic law.

verses.text: The people of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the LORD. They forgot the LORD their God and served the Baals and the Asheroth.
verses.comment: The cycle begins: idolatry and abandonment of God.

verses.text: Therefore the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and He sold them into the hand of Cushan-rishathaim, king of Mesopotamia. And the people of Israel served Cushan-rishathaim eight years.
verses.comment: God's judgment results in oppression from a foreign king.

verses.text: But when the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, the LORD raised up a deliverer for the people of Israel, who saved them: Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother.
verses.comment: Othniel is the first judge; reaffirms his lineage.

verses.text: The Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he judged Israel. He went out to war, and the LORD gave Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia into his hand, and his hand prevailed over Cushan-rishathaim.
verses.comment: God empowers Othniel for victory.

verses.text: So the land had rest for forty years. Then Othniel the son of Kenaz died.
verses.comment: Marks the end of the first judge's period of peace.

verses.text: And the people of Israel again did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, and the LORD strengthened Eglon the king of Moab against Israel, because they had done what was evil in the sight of the LORD.
verses.comment: Another cycle begins with Israel's sin.

verses.text: He gathered to himself the Ammonites and the Amalekites, and went and struck Israel. And they took possession of the city of palms.
verses.comment: City of palms refers to Jericho.

verses.text: And the people of Israel served Eglon the king of Moab eighteen years.
verses.comment: Eighteen years of subjugation.

verses.text: But when the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, the LORD raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud, the son of Gera, the Benjaminite, a left-handed man. The people of Israel sent tribute by him to Eglon the king of Moab.
verses.comment: Left-handedness is notable; Benjamin means 'son of the right hand.'

verses.text: And Ehud made himself a sword with two edges, a cubit in length, and he bound it under his right thigh, under his clothes.
verses.comment: Cubit: about 18 inches or 45 centimeters.

verses.text: And he presented the tribute to Eglon king of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man.
verses.comment: Describes Eglon's physique, significant for the story.

verses.text: And when Ehud had finished presenting the tribute, he sent away the people who carried the tribute.
verses.comment: Sets up Ehud's solo interaction.

verses.text: But he himself turned back at the carved idols near Gilgal and said, "I have a secret message for you, O king." And he commanded, "Silence." And all who attended him went out from his presence.
verses.comment: Carved idols: may refer to pagan images or boundary stones.

verses.text: And Ehud came to him while he was sitting alone in his cool upper chamber. And Ehud said, "I have a message from God for you." And he arose from his seat.
verses.comment: Cool upper chamber: a private, roof-level room.

verses.text: Then Ehud reached with his left hand, took the sword from his right thigh, and thrust it into his belly.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Ehud’s left-handedness, supporting the element of surprise.

verses.text: And the hilt also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade, for he did not pull the sword out of his belly, and the dung came out.
verses.comment: Graphic description; 'dung came out' is faithful to the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then Ehud went out onto the porch and closed the doors of the upper chamber behind him and locked them.
verses.comment: Porch may also be translated as 'vestibule' or 'gallery.'

verses.text: When he had gone, the servants came and saw that the doors of the upper chamber were locked. They said, "Surely he is relieving himself in the cool chamber."
verses.comment: Literal: 'covering his feet,' a Hebrew euphemism for relieving oneself.

verses.text: And they waited until they were embarrassed. But when he still did not open the doors of the upper chamber, they took the key and opened them, and there lay their lord dead on the floor.
verses.comment: 'Embarrassed': indicates an awkward wait, unsure if they should disturb the king.

verses.text: Ehud escaped while they delayed, and he passed beyond the carved idols and escaped to Seirah.
verses.comment: Seirah likely in the hill country of Ephraim.

verses.text: When he arrived, he sounded the trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim. Then the people of Israel went down with him from the hill country, and he was their leader.
verses.comment: Trumpet call was a summons to battle.

verses.text: And he said to them, "Follow after me, for the LORD has given your enemies the Moabites into your hand." So they went down after him and seized the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites and did not allow anyone to cross over.
verses.comment: Controlling the fords trapped the enemy.

verses.text: And they struck down at that time about ten thousand men of Moab, all strong, able-bodied men; not a man escaped.
verses.comment: 'Strong, able-bodied' is literal: 'robust, powerful men.'

verses.text: So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest for eighty years.
verses.comment: Longest period of rest in Judges.

verses.text: After him was Shamgar the son of Anath, who killed six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad, and he also saved Israel.
verses.comment: Oxgoad: agricultural tool used as an improvised weapon.
